learning_outcomes: Students can interpret slope and y-intercept in context

global_benchmarks.adaptation_notes: Used Singapore's visual approach to slope but replaced Western examples with Liberian contexts

title: Understanding Linear Functions
description: Students learn to graph linear functions and interpret slope and y-intercept in real-world Liberian contexts
prerequisites: Students can plot points on a coordinate plane

learning_objectives.statement: Students will graph a linear function given in slope-intercept form (y = mx + b)
success_criteria: Uses slope to find second point

learning_objectives.statement: Students will interpret slope and y-intercept in the context of a Liberian real-world problem
success_criteria: Explains what slope represents (rate of change)

activities.title: Introduction: Market Stall Revenue
activities.description: Visual story of a market vendor's daily revenue to introduce the concept of linear change

instructions.student: Watch the animation showing Ma Fatu's cassava sales. Notice how her revenue grows steadily each hour.
instructions.teacher: Present the market vendor scenario. Ask: 'How much does Ma Fatu earn per hour? How much did she start with?' Use this to introduce slope and y-intercept informally.

materials.name: Market vendor animation
materials.alternative: Teacher can draw on board or use printed images

differentiation.struggling: Use physical Liberian dollar bills to model the problem
differentiation.advanced: Ask students to predict revenue at hour 10
differentiation.mixed_literacy: Strong visual with minimal text, audio narration available

activities.title: Graphing Practice
activities.description: Students graph 3 linear functions with immediate feedback

instructions.student: Graph each function on the coordinate plane. Use the slope and y-intercept to help you.
instructions.teacher: Circulate and check for common errors: wrong y-intercept placement, incorrect use of slope. Provide hints, not answers.

materials.name: Graph paper (digital or printed)
materials.alternative: Students can draw coordinate planes in notebooks

differentiation.struggling: Provide pre-drawn axes with labeled points

activities.title: Real-World Application
activities.description: Students solve word problems about taxi fares, phone credit, and water usage

instructions.student: Read each problem carefully. Identify the slope (rate) and y-intercept (starting value). Write the equation and answer the question.
instructions.teacher: Model the first problem together. Emphasize identifying what changes (slope) vs. what stays constant (y-intercept).

materials.name: Word problem worksheet
materials.alternative: Problems read aloud or written on board

differentiation.struggling: Provide sentence frames: 'The slope is ___ because...'
differentiation.advanced: Add a problem with two linear functions to compare
differentiation.mixed_literacy: Problems use simple vocabulary, context is familiar (taxis, markets)

questions.question: What is the slope of the line y = 3x + 5?
questions.explanation: In slope-intercept form y = mx + b, m is the slope. Here, m = 3.
hints: Remember: y = mx + b, where m is the slope
The slope is the number in front of x

questions.question: A taxi in Monrovia charges LD 50 to start, then LD 20 per kilometer. Which equation represents the total cost C after k kilometers?
questions.explanation: The starting cost (LD 50) is the y-intercept. The per-kilometer charge (LD 20) is the slope. So C = 20k + 50.
hints: What stays the same regardless of distance?
What changes as the kilometers increase?
Use the form: Total = (rate Ã— distance) + starting cost

feedback.correct: Excellent work! You understand linear functions.
feedback.incorrect: Not quite. Review the lesson and try again. You can do this!
feedback.partial: You're on the right track. Check your work on questions {failed_ids}.

local_examples: Ma Fatu's cassava market stall (revenue per hour)
Monrovia taxi fares (flat rate + per km)
Mobile phone credit (base cost + per minute)
Community well water collection (liters per trip)
cultural_context.language_notes: Use 'Liberian dollar (LD)' consistently. Pronounce 'kilometer' as 'kill-oh-meter' in audio.
community_connections: Students can interview local vendors about pricing
Compare taxi fares across different routes in Monrovia

common_misconceptions.misconception: Students think the y-intercept is the x-value where the line crosses the y-axis
common_misconceptions.correction: The y-intercept is the y-value when x = 0. It's the height where the line crosses the y-axis.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Students confuse slope with y-intercept in word problems
common_misconceptions.correction: Ask: 'What changes as x increases?' (slope) vs. 'What's the starting value?' (y-intercept)

prerequisite_check: Can plot points (x, y) on a coordinate plane

lesson_plan.opening: Hook: Show market vendor visual. Ask 'How much does she earn per hour?' Connect to students' experiences with markets.
lesson_plan.direct_instruction: Teach slope-intercept form y = mx + b. Explain m = slope (rate of change), b = y-intercept (starting value). Show 2 examples on board.
lesson_plan.guided_practice: Work through graphing y = 2x + 3 together as a class. Think aloud: 'First, I plot the y-intercept at (0, 3). Then I use slope 2 to go up 2, right 1.'
lesson_plan.independent_practice: Students complete interactive graphing activity. Teacher circulates, provides hints.
lesson_plan.closing: Exit ticket: Graph one function and explain what slope/y-intercept mean in context.
lesson_plan.extension: Challenge: Can you write an equation for your family's monthly expenses?

parent_summary: This week, your child learned about linear functions in math. They practiced graphing lines and understanding how things change at a steady rate, like taxi fares or market sales. This skill helps with budgeting and planning.
